text:
The dance ball was truly a magical experience! From the moment of entry to the last dance of the evening, there was a captivating atmosphere that drew all guests in. The music was fantastic and immediately invited people to dance. The live band played a great mix of classic and modern dance music, creating the perfect mood to hit the dance floor.

The decoration was breathtaking and created an elegant and romantic atmosphere that immediately captivated every guest. The venue itself was spacious and provided enough room for all guests to dance comfortably. The dance floor was large enough to accommodate many couples without feeling crowded.

The organizers did everything to ensure that the ball ran smoothly and guests felt comfortable. The staff was friendly and accommodating, making sure that the drinks and food were always fresh and delicious.

All in all, the dance ball was an unforgettable experience. From the beautiful atmosphere to the fantastic music and excellent service - everything was perfect! If you're looking for an unforgettable evening full of dance, music, and good company, I highly recommend this dance ball!

text:
Hofburg tappa obbligatoria, cos� come la Reggia di Schonbrunn

In vacanza a Vienna nel periodo pre natalizio, decidiamo di visitare questo museo per far conoscere (anche) alle nostre bimbe, attraverso il mito della principessa Sissi, un po' di storia.
All'ingresso � possibile usufruire di sconti famiglia e gratuitamente viene consegnata, per ogni visitatore (bambini compresi), un'audio guida. Temevamo che le nostre bambine, di anni 7 e 5, potessero annoiarsi, invece hanno risposto benissimo e per loro � stato wuasinun gioco il dover cercare e seguire i numeri progressivi posti lungo il percorso che servivano per ascoltare contenuti nuovi attraverso l'audio guida: � stata un po' come una caccia al tesoro.
Nel museo, prima di salire per visitare gli splendidi appartamenti, � possibile ammirare al piano terra preziosissime collezioni di porcellane finissime, argenterie e fantastici centro tavola d'epoca, magnificamente conservati.
La visita dura circa 90/120 minuti.

text: This was a pretty nice hotel in a reasonable location. We had a few minor issues during our 3 night stay, such as TV remote not working, adjoining room door being unlocked and ajar, and the room key being wiped multiple times, however, on the whole, our experience was a positive one. The room we were allocated was very spacious and the air conditioning worked faultlessly. The bathroom was small but perfectly serviceable (albeit in need of some minor TLC). The staff we encountered were mostly friendly and helpful. A massive shout out to the the hotel General Manager who, after numerous staff were hit by covid, stepped in to fulfil night porter duties. I would definitely stay here again.

Austria Attractions - Hofburg

There are many large museum buildings around Liberty Square
The whole area is a very significant Austro-Hungarian Empire building complex
Among them, the Hofburg is located at the Heroes Square.
This is the Winter Palace of the Austrian Habsburgs
In the 13th century it was only a defensive tower
With the continuous expansion of the Habsburg dynasty and Vienna
It eventually became the place where the royal family lived

text:
What impressed me at the Hofburg Palace was the Sisi Museum. Sisi's private life is at the center of the exhibitions: her revolt against court ceremonies, her escape into the cult of beauty, her obsession with being in shape, her athletic performances, her poetry. From her carefree days as a young girl in Bavaria to her surprising engagement to the Emperor of Austria and her assassination in Geneva in 1898, the museum illustrates the turbulent life of the legendary empress.

Such a mysterious, melancholic character with a very tragic and sad destiny.

I also enjoyed visiting the Imperial Treasury. You cannot help but be impressed by the grandeur and opulence of this place. But at the same time, it makes you think about the price of how many lives suffer to create these objects, clothes, etc.

text: Great palace, huge actually. They say nobody knows the exact number of rooms in all the buildings that are a part of it. From a tourist perspective, though, it's a very, very confusing place. There are s number of museums in it, and the people from one museum can't give you even the most basic information about the other, for example the working hours or even the building location. There are no signs, we asked multiple times and were given repeatedly wrong information and directions. Once at the site, it took us more than half an hour to find a particular museum. It's s huge mess and no one seems to care about it. We ended up spending much less time there compared to what we had planned because of all the confusion.

text:
Part of Hofburg Palace, Neue Burg, flanks Heroes� Square, but most of the palace is located further down on Michaelerplatz. Built in the 13th century, Hofburg Palace was the seat of power of the Habsburg Empire for several centuries.
It was expanded several times and now consists of (amongst others) the imperial chapel, the imperial library, the treasury, the Spanish Riding School, and the imperial mews.
Although some parts of the palace are currently closed to visitors, one of the most popular tourist attractions is the Imperial Apartments which transport you back several hundred years to an age of splendour and indulgence.
If you do not have time to visit Sch�nbrunn Palace, you may want to consider visiting Hofburg Palace instead.

text:
The Hofburg is the former principal imperial palace of the Habsburg dynasty. Located in the centre of Vienna, it was built in the 13th century and expanded several times afterwards. It also served as the imperial winter residence, as Sch�nbrunn Palace was the summer residence. Since 1946 it is the official residence and workplace of the president of Austria.

Since 1279 the Hofburg area has been the documented seat of government.[1] The Hofburg has been expanded over the centuries to include various residences (with the Amalienburg and the Albertina), the imperial chapel (Hofkapelle or Burgkapelle), the imperial library (Hofbibliothek), the treasury (Schatzkammer), the Burgtheater, the Spanish Riding School (Hofreitschule), the imperial mews (Stallburg and Hofstallungen).

The palace faces the Heldenplatz (Heroes Square) ordered under the reign of Emperor Franz Joseph I, as part of what was planned to become the Kaiserforum [de] but which was never completed.

Numerous architects have executed work at the Hofburg as it expanded, notably the Italian architect-engineer Filiberto Luchese, Lodovico Burnacini and Martino and Domenico Carlone, the Baroque architects Lukas von Hildebrandt and Joseph Emanuel Fischer von Erlach, Johann Fischer von Erlach, and the architects of the Neue Burg built between 1881 and 1913.

text: The place is MASSIVE! It has so much history and so many things to see! From the silver museum to the library to the sisi museum to the imperial rooms! It's a lot of fun but the tour is really long (about 90 minutes or so). The audio guide experience is really good! I got to learn a lot of things about the history of Austria and about the royal family!  Some criticisms are that we can't take pictures at parts of the place (like sisi museum and imperial rooms) and that we can't connect Bluetooth earbuds to the audio guide remote. The amount of things you learn there is so much worth it though and the place is very well priced! I had a lot of fun there.

text: Die Hofburg ist einfach sensationell und nicht nur einen Besuch wert! Es lassen sich bestimmt problemlos zwei volle Tage hier verbringen, wenn man alles erkunden will. Wir haben die Silberkammer, die Kaiserappartements, das Sisi-Museum sowie den Prunksaal der Nationalbibliothek besucht. Leider wurde die Silberkammer in meinem Reisef�hrer in zwei S�tzen abgehandelt, so dass ich nicht im Ansatz erahnt habe, wie umfangreich die Sammlung tats�chlich ist. Allerdings sind die G�nge eng und mit Rucksack wird es gelegentlich etwas  unhandlich. Dennoch lohnt es sich, hier ausreichend Zeit einzuplanen, denn die schiere Masse an Exponaten ist �berw�ltigend. Das Sisi-Museum �berzeugt ebenfalls mit einer unglaublichen F�lle an Gegenst�nden und Kleidungsst�cken von Elisabeth und vermittelt im Zusammenspiel mit den Audioguides einen tollen Eindruck von Elisabeths Leben. In den Kaiserappartements f�hlt man sich sofort in die Kaiserzeit zur�ckversetzt und hat das Gef�hl, dass jeden Augenblick eine Zofe um die n�chste Ecke huschen wird. Alles in allem wird die damalige Zeit sehr lebendig und anschaulich vermittelt, so dass auch interessierte Kinder ihre helle Freude an diesen Museen haben k�nnen. Das n�chste Highlight ist der Prunksaal der Nationalbibliothek. Hier fehlen mir einfach die Worte f�r so viel Sch�nheit und �sthetik. Er ist absolut sehenswert, ein Besuch der Hofburg bzw. Wien OHNE den Prunksaal Ost im Grunde grob fahrl�ssig. Allerdings muss man wissen, dass es keinen Aufzug gibt und der Aufstieg �ber breite, historische Treppen erfolgt. Wenn �ltere Personen also eine Verschnaufpause einlegen m�ssen, hat man Gelegenheit, auch dieses sch�ne Treppenhaus n�her zu betrachten.

text:
The Vienna Hofburg is one of the largest palace complexes in the world.
The oldest parts date from the 13th century, and construction continued into the 20th century.
The Hofburg was the residence and government center of the Habsburg emperors until 1918.
Today there are numerous museums with outstanding collections, the Spanish Riding School, a congress center, the seat of the Austrian Federal President and the historic Heldenplatz.

text:
The�Hofburg�is the former principal imperial palace of the�Habsburg�dynasty. Located in the�center�of�Vienna, it was built in the 13th century and expanded several times afterwards. It also served as the imperial winter residence, as�Sch�nbrunn Palace�was the summer residence. Since 1946 it is the�official residence�and�workplace�of the�President of Austria.
Since 1279 the Hofburg area has been the documented seat of government.�The Hofburg has been expanded over the centuries to include various residences (with the�Amalienburg�and the�Albertina), the imperial chapel (Hofkapelle�or�Burgkapelle), the�imperial library�(Hofbibliothek), the�treasury�(Schatzkammer), the�Burgtheater, the�Spanish Riding School�(Hofreitschule), the imperial�mews�(Stallburg�and�Hofstallungen).
The palace faces the�Heldenplatz�(Heroes Square) ordered under the reign of Emperor�Franz Joseph I, as part of what was planned to become the�Kaiserforum�[de]�but which was never completed.
Numerous architects have executed work at the Hofburg as it expanded, notably the Italian architect-engineer Filiberto Luchese,�Lodovico Burnacini�and Martino and Domenico Carlone, the�Baroque�architects�Lukas von Hildebrandt�and�Joseph Emanuel Fischer von Erlach,�Johann Fischer von Erlach, and the architects of the�Neue Burg�built between 1881 and 1913.
The name translates as "Castle of the Court", which denotes its origins when initially constructed during the�Middle Ages. Initially planned in the 13th century as the seat of the�Dukes of Austria, the palace expanded over the centuries, as they became increasingly powerful. From 1438 to 1583, and again from 1612 to 1806, it was the seat of the Habsburg kings and emperors of the�Holy Roman Empire, and thereafter until 1918 the seat of the�Emperors of Austria. Since then the palace has continued in its role as the seat of the head of state and is today used by the Austrian Federal President.

Il complesso dell�Hofburg � indubbiamente una delle visite obbligate quando si visita Vienna.
L�origine risale al XIII secolo ma nei quasi 800 anni di dominio asburgico venne ambulato e abbellito proporzionalmente all�impero stesso.
La Heldenplatz con la statua equestre dell�Arciduca Carlo d�Austria, introduce alla magnificenza ed alla bellezza che si troveranno negli appartamenti reali (I pi� famosi quelli della principessa Sisi: Elisabetta di Baviera) e nella collezione dei tesori imperiali, ai quali si accede dall�edificio retrostante la statua.
Il complesso di compone anche della Biblioteca Nazionale, del museo dell�Albertina, dei man�ggi e della Scuola di Equitazione Spagnola (dove si addestravano i cavalli di Lipizza) e di vari parchi curati come come gioielli.

text:
Die Hofburg ist neben dem Stephansdom mit die erste Adresse, die man in der Innenstadt Wiens anschauen sollte.

Ein sehr imposantes Geb�ude, in dem man viel �ber das Kaisserreich und die Habsburger-Dynastie lernt.

Als treusorgender Lebenspartner geht man nat�rlich auch mit in die Sissi-Ausstellung und lernt dort interessanterweise, dass die Kaiserin Elisabeth nur bedingt so war, wie einem die zahlreichen romantisierten Verfilmungen weismachen wollen.

Die R�umlichkeiten der Kaiserfamilie sind sehr eindrucksvoll und wer etwas Interesse an Geschichte hat, macht hier nichts verkehrt. Einen Audio-Guide gibt es kostenlos.

Als Tipp: Das Kombi-Ticket Sissi Deluxe kaufen, wenn man auch Schloss Sch�nbrunn besuchen will.

Etwas nervig ist der (bei Touristenattraktion wohl �bliche) Souvenier- und Merchandising-Shop am Ende, den man zwangsl�ufig durchqueren muss.

text:
A century ago Vienna was the centre of a mighty empire. 

The Hofburg was the home of the Habsburgs until 1918 � one of the largest and grandest palaces in the world, it looks a little like a huge, iced cake. Today you could happily lose yourself here for days.???

If you�ve only got time to visit one attraction in Vienna, make it this. The palace complex houses paintings by the likes of Klimt and Du?rer, the Spanish Riding School (home to the dancing Lipizzaner horses), a butterfly house and the Austrian Film Museum.

text:
Voor de Sisi-jurken en haar eigen verhaal is dit het museum om te bezoeken. Daarnaast krijg je een mooi kijkje in het hofleven van de keizerlijke familie. Het witerpaleis de Hofburg ligt vlakbij de Weense Opera. Vanaf de Weense Opera vertrekken bussen voor toeristen op vaste routes de stad door. Ook naar het zomerpaleis Schonbrunn waar Sisi met Frans Josef heeft gewoond.
De audiotour bij de ingang is aan te bevelen. Je kan hierdoor zelfstandig en op eigen tempo door de kamers dwalen.

text:
The Imperial palace of Hofburg has been since the 13th century the official residence and seat of power of the once royal and imperial house of Habsburg. Now, the palace serves as the official residence of the President of Austria. There are currently three areas of the large palace open for public. It is the Imperial Apartments, the Sisi Museum and the Silver Collection. You may buy a ticket for 13.90 Eur with the audio guide or 16.90 with a tourist guide. It is also possible to buy the so called Sisi Ticket for 27 EUR that gives you admission to the Hofburg palace, the Sch�nbrunn palace and Imperial Furniture Collection.

More on my Youtube channel Lex Universe :)
title: Hofburg Wien

text: Simply stunning! A person not normally interested in palaces or museums can easily spend half a day there without being bored even the slightest! Place demonstrates Austrian spirit quite well!  Trip allows to easily grasp Austrian art and history. The place is quite eye-pleasing and makes anyone feel like a guest in the house. Well preserved and with explanations available in English. There are shocking parts to the tour that only add to the place's character.

text: The Hofburg is the official residence and workplace of the President of Austria and was formerly the major prominent palace of the Habsburg empire. Located in the centre of Vienna, it was built in the 13th century and expanded various times afterwards. For over 600 years, the Vienna Hofburg stood the residence of the Austrian sovereigns. Over the centuries, it cultivated into one of the vastly important centres of European history. It was from here that the Habsburgs reigned from the 13th century, at first as rulers of the Austrian patrimonial lands, from 1452 as emperors of the Holy Roman Empire, and finally as emperors of Austria from 1806 until the end of the monarchy in 1918. The Hofburg area covers a�collection of formerly imperial buildings and open spaces that�now serve various purposes, from the President�s office to the National Library. As I said, The Hofburg fabricates at the centre of Vienna and can best be reached by underground or other public transport easily. The entrance to the museums is directly below the enormous copper dome named the Michaelerkuppel, reached via the Michaelertor, the gate on the north-eastern side of the palace on Michaelerplatz. At least everyone should see it once in their life

title: Hofburg Wien

text:
Vor 200 Jahren fand in der Hofburg der Wiener Kongress statt. Nach dem Sieg �ber Napoleon wurde der Frieden in Europa dort verhandelt. Das Ganze dauerte 9 Monate (1814/1815). Der russische Zar Alexander wohnte in der Hofburg und der �sterreicher Metternich leitete die Verhandlungen. Im Rahmen der Besichtigung des Sisi Museums und der Kaiserappartements konnte man einen sehr guten Eindruck �ber die damaligen R�umlichkeiten gewinnen.

Die Silberkammer der Hofburg kann kostenlos besichtigt werden. Sie liegt im Erdgeschoss und von dort ist das Sisi-Museum im ersten Obergeschoss zu erreichen (das Eintritt kostet). In der Silberkammer sind eindrucksvolle Arbeiten zu besichtigen und man ist von der F�lle und der Bedeutung f�r die Habsburger �berrascht.

Medienstar wurde Sisi (die �sterreichische Kaiserin Elisabeth) erst lange nach ihrem Tode. Ihre Ehe mit Kaiser Franz Joseph war ein gro�es Ungl�ck und sie litt ihr Leben lang unter Depressionen. Entsprechende Informationen finden sich im Sisi Museum in der Hofburg. Man kann auch ihre Gem�cher und die von ihrem Gatten besichtigen.

title: Hofburg Wien

text:
The Hofburg was the residence of the Habsburgs in Vienna from the 13th century until 1918 (with interruptions). Since the end of 1946 it has been the official residence of the Austrian Federal President. It houses most of the Austrian National Library as well as various museums (including the Albertina) and the Federal Monuments Office.

The area, which has grown over the course of about seven centuries, covers an area of approximately 24 hectares, making it the largest building complex built for non-religious purposes in Europe.[1] The complex also includes two sacred buildings: the Hofburg Chapel and the Augustinian Church. If one adds the area of the museums (KHM and NHM), including the old court stables - today's MuseumsQuartier - to the Hofburg area, one arrives at a total area of about 50 hectares.

Around 5,000 people live or work on the Hofburg grounds, which together with Heldenplatz are visited by around 20 million people a year.[2] The Hofburg is the property of the Republic of Austria and is administered by the Burghauptmannschaft.

Il palazzo adibito a residenza invernale della famiglia imperiale. Le numerosissime sale e stanze si distinguono per grandezza e sfarzo. Consigliato affittare una guida (anche solamente un un'audioguida) per poter immergersi al meglio nella storia del palazzo e scoprire i segreti che si celano tra i suoi corridoi. Passateci se siete in visita in citt�.
La mia ultima visita risale al 2019.

The palace used to be the winter residence of the imperial family. The numerous halls and rooms are characterized by their size and splendor. We recommend hiring a guide (even just an audio guide) to better immerse yourself in the history of the building and discover the secrets that lie among its corridors. Come by if you are visiting the city.
My last visit dates back to 2019.

text: La visita del castello la trovo una tappa essenziale per scoprire l'anima di questa citt� imperiale e austera. L'audioguida � compresa nel prezzo ed � stata molto utile a tutti (grandi e piccini). Alle mie bimbe sono piaciuti in particolare i vestiti e le camere dell'imperatrice (soprattutto la camera con gli attrezzi per allenarsi). Consiglio la visita, anche con bambini.
title: Hofburg Wien

text:
Il biglietto base include il museo degli argenti, il museo di Sissi e gli appartamenti imperiali.
Il museo degli argenti � il pi� grande, include una gran quantit� di servizi da tavola, da toeletta e candelabri. Argento, oro e porcellane decorate.
Il museo di Sissi include alcuni suoi abiti, oggetti personali e documenti.
Gli appartamenti imperiali sono alcune stanze (non molte) tra cui lo studio dell'imperatore, la sua stanza da letto, la stanza di Sissi e le sue sale private (tra cui il bagno, che per una reggia europea � una cosa piuttosto moderna).
Note positive:
-hanno aggiunto dei ventilatori Dyson nelle stanze, quindi d'estate non fa pi� caldo.
-grazie al Covid i visitatori sono relativamente pochi. Siamo stati in fila 2 minuti, e nessuno ci ha spinto via dalle sale. In una ci siamo anche messi a disegnare con calma.
-l'argenteria � davvero bella e ben tenuta, cos� come gli appartamenti imperiali.
Note negative:
-le norme anti Covid sono molto deludenti. C'� tanto zelo per non farti fare foto, ma nessuno dice niente se i turisti si accalcano. E non � a essere cattivi, ma la gente quando guarda i musei diventa scema, ti cammina addosso come se fossi invisibile. Se non li riprendi mai, � chiaro che poi il distanziamento non lo rispettano! I corridoi sono stretti, il minimo che si possa fare � cercare di non ammassarsi.
-la stanza di Sissi � in ristrutturazione, e non � segnato all'ingresso.
-nel museo di Sissi si impara poco sulla sua vita, anche se immagino che l'audioguida pagata a parte potrebbe colmare la lacuna...
-non si possono fare foto, e non � indicato all'ingresso. In compenso niente vieta di ottenere riproduzioni visive con metodi alternativi, cos� quando abbiamo visto una ragazza ripresa perch� scattava una foto ci siamo seduti, abbiamo tirato fuori gli sketchbook e con un sorriso ci siamo messi a riprodurre a mano gli abiti di Sissi. Prima a matita, poi acquerelli e penna tanto per dare profondit� e aggiungere dettagli. Per 40 minuti buoni, occupando due delle 4 sedie nella sala. E niente, � buffo quanto sarebbe stato meglio per loro lasciarci prendere una foto e basta...
Cos'�, hanno paura che se diffondessimo le foto di un vestito che tra l'altro si trova gi� su Google la gente cambierebbe idea o se ne andasse? O peggio, non comprasse le loro cartoline? Io ve la butto l�, dipingere non � vietato. O fare serigrafie. O bassorilievi. Sono italiano e gioco a Magic, SO come aggirare un divieto.

text: El Palacio de Hofburg es el m�s grande de Viena, fue la residencia de los emperadores de Austria-Hungria. Ahora es la residencia del presidente de la Rep�blica Austr�aca. Sus aposentos imperiales son imprecionante, tambi�n funciona all� La Escuela Espa�ola De Equitaci�n. Tambi�n tiene una Capilla, una Iglesia y la hermosa y majestuosa Biblioteca Nacional de Austria, construida por el Emperador Carlos VI en el siglo XVI, estilo Barroco. Es una de las bibliotecas hist�ricas m�s bonita del mundo y conserva m�s de 200.000 libros impresos entre los a�os 1500 y 1850. Adem�s tiene 8 millones de libros el Museo Del Papiro y el Museo Del Globo Terr�queo. El recorrido por el palacio tarda m�s o menos dos horas. Tambi�n posee unos jardines preciosos. Unos de los espacios m�s vicitado fue d�nde vivi� la Emperatriz Sisi, qui�n fue una mujer delicada de salud debido a su obsesi�n por mantenerse muy delgada. La Biblioteca me gust� much�simo , posee una buena exposici�n permanente sobre la vida y la obra del genial compositor Beethoven, sus partituras originales. Es una gozada poder ver tanta informaci�n acerca de �l y al mismo tiempo poder escuchar la mejestuocidad de su m�sica, es incre�ble y asombrosas.

text: All'Hofburg potrete vedere e visitare molto pi� di quello che immaginate! All'Hofburg ci sono gli appartamenti imperiali (ovvero di Francesco Giuseppe), gli appartamenti di Sissi, il museo delle argenterie e la scuola spagnola dei cavalli lipizziani. I primi 3 sono visitabili con un biglietto acquistabile in loco (ma anche on line) nel ticket office lato destro entrando sotto l'arco di ingresso al palazzo, mentre per la scuola dei cavalli lipizzani il ticket office � sul lato sinistro. In entrambi i casi occhio agli orari di apertura, ma soprattutto di chiusura (sono molto rigorosi!) e considerate eventuali file (ad esempio, il 14 febbraio 2020 di venerd� l'esercizio mattutino della scuola spagnola ha fatto il tutto esaurito, e di sicuro non eravamo in alta stagione). I biglietti per il trittico museo + 2 appartamenti imperiali e di Sissi, prevede anche la fornitura di un'audioguida in italiano e la visita complessiva richiede sulle 2 ore (dipende anche se al museo opterete per il giro corto da 20 minuti o quello lungo da 40). Ovviamente ad attrarre principalmente i turisti � il mito dell'iconica kaiserin Elisabeth ovvero dell'imperatrice Elisabetta Sissi come la chiamiamo in Italia, Sisi con una sola "s" come la chiamano in Austria), che al di l� dei film che l'hanno consacrata tale, anche nella realt� � stata un personaggio interessante e piuttosto controcorrente per i tempi in cui � vissuta!

text:
Not to be missed on a visit to Vienna. The ticket priced at 15 euros pp includes entry to 3 attractions in the palace with audio guide - the Silver collection, the Imperial apartments and a part giving the history of Princess Elizabeth (Sissi).

The whole tour with audio guide takes around 3 hours, and while it is tiring (there are chairs on which you can rest mid-tour), it is never boring.

text: Het imposante paleis van de Habsburgse aartshertogen en sinds 1945 de offici�le residentie van de bondspresident. De keizerlijke vertrekken van de wereldberoemde keizer Frans Jozef en keizerin Elisabeth (Sisi) zijn onveranderd gebleven en te bezichtigen. Een bezoek is aanbevelenswaardig. Tevens kan men het Sisi museum, de zilver collectie en keizerlijke schatten bezichtigen. Een rondleiding door het Sisi museum toont hoe de mythe van de keizerin Sisi is ontstaan. Een kijkje in haar persoonlijke vertrekken completeren het geheel.

text: Amazing architecture and it's huge. The Sisi museum is a must see and is accessible even for people with disabilities. Price for an adult si 15� and it includes the Sisi museum and the silverware collection, infortunately it is not allowed to take pictures of the inside of the museum. You can easily spend more than 2 hours in there. I loved the collection of things that belonged to empress Sisi but i wish they had more of her gown and clothes displayed but unfortunately there is only 3-4  gowns on display in the museum. The whole collecion of Sisi belongings is not too big, in fact you get to see more forniture and paintings that her belongings. I loved it even though i went there specifically to see more empress related stuff not just rooms and forniture

text:
Tappa obbligatoria di qualsiasi viaggio a Vienna!
Un tuffo nel passato, per scoprire tradizioni e modi di vivere degli imperatori, ma anche per immergersi nella travagliata vita della Principessa Sissi!
Particolarmente curato il servizio di audio guida, che crea un percorso molto interessante, tutto da vivere!
Assolutamente da visitare!

text: The Sissi Museum is well structurated, at the ground floor you can see a lot of imperial supplies. At the first floor you can find Sissi's and Franz Joseph's personal quotes, stuffs etc. If you want to see everything and not in a rush count min. 3 hours for this. Negative was that they have no gardrobe, you should carry on always your coat, umbrella etc. Some places inside the museum it was very cold and in other places very warm. The audio guide is without headphones, you can use it as a mobile phone and it is not so comfortable.

text:
What a grand place this is!

If you love beautiful buildings then come here, if you love seeing how the other half live then come here.

The buildings stands out and once inside you start off looking at the silver collection and once you've been through them you head into the history of Sissi the famous empress of Austria

This is a great place to learn some history of Vienna before heading into the rest of the city, so it gives you some nice background.

You'll spend about 2-3 hours here

text: The�Hofburg�is the former principal imperial palace of the Habsburg dynasty rulers and today serves as the official residence and workplace of the President of Austria. ... It also served as the imperial winter residence, as Sch�nbrunn Palace was the summer residence.The Hofburg is the fantastically-preserved imperial residences of Vienna; most famous for accommodating the Habsburg dynasty and serving as the playground for Austrian royalty through the ages. This is a sumptuous set of opulent architecture. many of the buildings charge entry, but you can access some parts for free

I like the history and the palace and treasury were amazing. I could have done without the porcelain and place setting tour but you have to go through it to get to the Imperial apartments. The 3 star rating is for the rude service staff and the ticket counter. I�m sorry but if you are in the service industry learn to smile, be nice to

text:
If someone has seen any other palaces it is doubtful if this visit worths.

Silver collection consists of  plates, forks and candlesticks; beautiful but nothing special or extraordinary. There are some nice plates and the candlesticks are really glory, but in most palaces there are similar item's.

Sisi's museum is just a tourist attraction, a few items and most of them are replications.

Imperial apartments are very simple, empty and without variety in their themes. Museums have more rich and beautiful rooms thanks these.

Also photography is forbidden

text:
The Hofburg Palace used to be an imperial palace that now houses 3 museums, consisting of the Imperial Silver Collection, Sisi Museum and Imperial Apartments. You get a discount if you have the Vienna City Card.

Really loved the sheer scale of the museums, where you can get to see three facets of the imperial Vienna life. The silver collection is mainly on the silverware used for meals by the imperial family, while the other two are self explanatory.

The explanation and exhibits are detailed and interesting. Do get the audio guide if you have time to spend, as with the audio guide you can spend 2 to 3 hours here. A good place to visit if you're a history and Sisi fan, and if you want a peek into life of the imperial family.

text: Il prezzo del biglietto vale la bellezza della visita e degli ambienti. Audioguida ben fatta. Merita e suggerisco di non tralasciare questa visita se si viene a Vienna anche se per pochi giorni. Sembra di ritornare indietro nel passato. Colpisce molto lo sfarzo delle stoviglie, delle tappezzerie e degli oggetti della vita quotidiana. Al termine della visita si ha un'immagine corretta di Sissi. Tra l'altro ho visitato il palazzo con un passeggino e non ho avuto grossi problemi. Prezzo di ingresso, 15 euro con audioguida compresa nel prezzo.

text: I underestimated how long it would take to navigate the Imperial Silver Collection; don't make my mistake!  The audio tour is offered in several languages but is a little long-winded for my taste. I recommend taking the abridged version.  The majority of The Hofburg is also #accessabilityfriendly! text:
All about my second Europe Trip-

Dear Travelers,
Hope all of you are busy planning your next trip!
My Solo Trip to Central Europe covering Prague ,Vienna and Budapest with a layover of 24hrs each (To and Fro) at Helsinki(Finland) got over. 9N and 10D was never going to be enough.It was hectic but what was more satisfying is all the boxes as planned got ticked.

Life in Europe is alluring to a point that you might get into depression ( I was to be honest) while coming back but then that's the fun.So much to explore and learn from cross culture.

Might like checking the posts in my time line. Posting few to entice.

Will be happy to help with queries .

text:
Siamo stati trasportati indietro nel tempo con l'aiuto delle audio guide (gratuite, diaponibili in lingue europee ed internazionali) che raccontano della principessa e tutto quel che la riguardava..
Si possono osservare delle riproduzioni dei gioielli di corte, abiti, e anche la stanza dell'imperatrice..
Abbiamo avuto un vero e proprio cuadro della loro vita di tutti i giorni: come l'imperatore gestiva gli incontri, una giornata tipo di Sissi, gli articoli da toeletta, abiti gioielli....

text:
Situated in the heart of Vienna, the Hofburg Palace chronicles the tale of Austrian history and social changes spanning over 500 years. It served as the imperial residence of many Habsburg monarchs that reign over Holy Roman Empire and neighboring kingdoms and thereafter the seat of emperors of Austria. Today the Hofburg fulfills the same role for the Republic of Austria as the official residence of the President.
The palatial complex received numberous expansions and alternations over the centuries under the order of nearly every ruler who resided there as they became increasingly powerful. As a result, the Hofburg accomendates a variety of architectural styles, from Gothic to Renaissance, Baroco to Neoclassicism.
I would recommend to look towards the Hofburg from Heldenplatz Square to appreciate the grandeur of this architectural complex accentuated against the backdrop of expansive sky.
Be sure to check out a counterpart of the Hofburg, Shc�nbrunn Palace which served Habsburg as their summer palace garnished in Rococo style.

text: Another highlight of Vienna. The Hofburg also contains the Viennese Riding School for the famous Lipizzaner horses. Be careful when buying tickets for any show at the school. The more expensive tickets are for shows when the horses actually perform. But you can also get tickets to shows where the horses are just exercised. These go on for several hours. Interesting for the first 30 mins and then Zzzzzzzz. You�re also barred from taking photos but it�s quite easy to avoid the photo-bouncers.c

text: I think The Hofburg is the most beautiful historic monument in Vienna. It's beautiful carvings are must see artifacts. They awe you with their beauty. It's quite like the Buckingham palace in London and even from the inside. The historic "Amorem Meum Populis Meis" status of FRANCIS II is situated here. You must visit this place and spend about 30 min here and absorb the history. There are horse cart and personal tours available in the area that you can do on a per person/hour basis. Though it's very doable on foot or public transport as well.

Stay outside and enjoy the view.

You see such a small fraction of the buildings for one... Two, it's hot, crowded, and claustrophobia inducing.

The silver museum. It's cool if you like plates, I guess. If you don't like the same things as your grandmother, prepare to be bored.

Sissi museum, very little original pieces almost all reproductions.  Can you really call that a museum?

Imperial apartments, these were okay, but poor traffic flow leads to feeling trapped when you're want to move on from a room.

title: Hofburg Wien

text:
The palace is amazing, don't misunderstand my star review. However, the main focus of the tour is poor Empress Elisabeth (Sissi), who was like Princess Di. She didn't like the public spotlight, completely withdrew from public life after the suicide of her son, and hardly lived in Austria, preferring vacation palace in other countries. Her life ended tragically when she was assassinated for being royalty by a French anarchist, despite having attempted to give back to the people.

Now that you have this background, you might also find the commodification of her to be completely weird and distasteful. She is on every kind of souvenir, like she is a fictional, Austrian Disney princess. This poor woman has no peace in death.

Palazzo al centro della citt� pi� noto come il palazzo della principessa Sissy; forte presenza di architettura di elementi che vanno dal gotico al neoclassicismo, passando per il rinascimentale ed il barocco. Palace in the center of the city best known as the palace of Princess Sissy; strong presence of architecture of elements ranging from Gothic to Neoclassicism, passing through the Renaissance and the Baroque. Don't miss the view at the Spanish Riding School with its famous Lipizzaner horses. On some days it is possible to see them doing the exercises, very nice.

text:
Well, as the palace is really nice from the outside but the inside trip of Sisi apartments was short and not so splendid. All these palaces just show how redundant and unnecessary all these buildings were, with all the space wasted. Nothing really amazing in these empty spaces with expensive stuff which these days are not so good.
As I have mentioned I have visited only silver collection and Sisi apartments area so my comment is going to be only about that.

It's good to see the history of these buildings and what was going on, so an audio guide is a must. You can get know how annoying spoiled sissy was the Sisi. Oh well, this annoyance made me only more interested in this history so I didn't find it boring at least.

At the end, the trip of Sisi apartments was a bit short in comparison also to the price you need to pay for the ticket.

All interno di questo enorme complesso di edifici Hofburg, ha sede il museo di Sissi.

text:
The Hofburg is the former principal imperial palace of the Habsburg dynasty rulers and today serves as the official residence and workplace of the President of Austria. It is located in the center of Vienna and was built in the 13th century and expanded several times afterwards. It also served as the imperial winter residence, as Sch�nbrunn Palace was the summer residence. Since 1279 the Hofburg area has been the documented seat of government. The Hofburg has been expanded over the centuries to include various residences (with the Amalienburg and the Albertina), the imperial chapel (Hofkapelle or Burgkapelle), the imperial library (Hofbibliothek), the treasury (Schatzkammer), the Burgtheater, the Spanish Riding School (Hofreitschule), the imperial mews (Stallburg and Hofstallungen).

The palace faces the Heldenplatz (Heroes Square) ordered under the reign of Emperor Francis Joseph I, as part of what was planned to become the Kaiserforum [de] but which was never completed.

Numerous architects have executed work at the Hofburg as it expanded, notably the Italian architect-engineer Filiberto Luchese, Lodovico Burnacini and Martino and Domenico Carlone, the Baroque architects Lukas von Hildebrandt and Joseph Emanuel Fischer von Erlach, Johann Fischer von Erlach, and the architects of the Neue Burg built between 1881 and 1913.

The name translates as "Castle of the Court", which denotes its origins when initially constructed during the Middle Ages. Initially planned in the 13th century as the seat of the Dukes of Austria, the palace expanded over the centuries, as they became increasingly powerful. From 1438 to 1583, and again from 1612 to 1806, it was the seat of the Habsburg kings and emperors of the Holy Roman Empire, and thereafter until 1918 the seat of the Emperors of Austria. Since then the palace has continued in its role as the seat of the head of state and is today used by the Austrian Federal President.

It is also the permanent home of the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE).

The whole palace complex is under the administration of the governor (Burghauptmann), who in turn is part of the Burghauptmannschaft, an office which has been in existence since the Middle Ages under the auspices of the Burgrave. At present the Burghauptmannschaft is under the jurisdiction of the Federal Ministry of the Economy.

In September 1958, parts of the Hofburg were opened to the public as a convention centre. In the first ten years, the Burghauptmannschaft operated the convention centre; since 1969 a private company (HOFBURG Vienna - Wiener Kongresszentrum Hofburg Betriebsgesellschaft) has been managing the international congress and events center. Every year the convention centre hosts about 300 to 350 events, with around 300,000 to 320,000 guests. Among the events are conventions and meetings as well as banquets, trade fairs, concerts, and balls.

text:
The Hofburg itself is a massive Palace complex that is the official residence of the Austrian President. It is not uncommon to visit and see EU officials being shuttled in and out of the Palace with full Police and Security detail.
The Palace can be accessed via the Heldenplatz or the Michaelerplatz, so take some time to use both sides because the perspective is different.
The Palace itself is home to several museums and attractions that require tickets and usually have many people.
However most people visit the Hofburg to see the impressive architecture, take pictures and generally walk around. There is an onsite Cafe that you can sit and have a snack or coffee if you want.

text:
Fabulous hotel, nice room with disabled access and facilities. Great location, close to the main attractions but on a quiet street. Nice local restaurants and bars, local Spar and other shops and the English theatre is next door. Close to tube and tram stops.

Hotel staff were helpful and all our requests were dealt with. Lift big enough to accommodate my wheelchair and wet room shower with a chair, which is unusual  in such an old city.

The hotel is spotlessly clean and beautifully decorated.  Breakfast (hot and cold) has been superb, lovely courtyard area to eat alfresco in the sunshine. Ramp access and lots of nooks and crannies to sit and chat in make it a perfect hotel for a city break or business trip.

text: Of all our experiences touring Vienna, the Hofburg was our most disappointing.  While it�s impressive to see the displays and building, and we expect crowds, the actual crowd management was terrible! We made a point of pre-buying our tickets (more on that) , got there early and had to wait in line for 30 mins just to find out we could have walked in.  There was no way to find out as the second ticket-holding access was there: too many people, no signage, or greeter to answer questions. There was also no info online. Also a warning in general for many ticket purchases in Vienna: if you buy an online ticket, many found out the purchase was via a third party, and the print at home ticket will not give you instant access.  You have to wait in the ticket purchase line to exchange for a real ticket.

Gli ambienti, pur essendo un po' ristretti in alcune parti, anche per il folto numero dei visitatori, sono curati nei minimi particolari ed emanano un'atmosfera di lusso, sfarzo ed eleganza.
Con l'auto dell'audio guida � possibile gustare il percorso con informazioni e aneddoti.
Interessante anche la mostra di stoviglie dell'epoca, anche se meno coinvolgente.

L'esposizione comprende l'argenteria e le ceramiche di palazzo e un percorso dedicato alla principessa Sissi con annessa visita agli appartamenti reali.
La prima parte � veramente enorme, ci sono piatti,servizi interi da tavola,candelabri ecc..
Finch� non si vede dal vivo sembra poca cosa, ma una volta l� si rimane veramente colpiti dalla qualit� delle decorazioni e dalla variet�, ce n'� per tutti i gusti!
La seconda parte invece racconta la storia della Principessa e mostra oggetti e vestiti a lei appertenuti,tutti ben tenuti e interessanti. Poi ci si posta negli appartamenti reali, molto curati e ben illuminati.
Consigliato!

Ich glaube das beeindruckenste ist wohl nach wie vor das Geb�ude von au�en selbst. Die Besichtigung lohnt sich nur bedingt. Erst mal das positive: Das Porzellan und alles drum herum im EG ist wirklich beeindruckend, aber wir h�tten nicht gedacht, dass das letztlich das Highlight dieser Ausstellung ist. Wer sich f�r Sisi interessiert kann maximal noch gefallen an deren Kleidern empfinden, die teilweise in der oberen Ausstellung zu sehen sind.
Allerdings sind die G�nge sehr schmal und egal zu welcher Zeit, man wird quasi permanent von Asiaten und anderen umgerannt und es ist alles andere als gem�tlich. Die Wartezeiten sind teilweise wirklich unsch�n, an manchen Stellen kann man gar nicht weiter gehen.
Der letzte Raum dann mit dem gedeckten Tisch war noch beeindruckend. Die Prunkr�ume sind nur teilweise sehenswert, da ist Sch�nbrunn einfach beeindruckender. Ich m�chte das jetzt nicht klein reden, aber man erwartet im Vorfeld viel mehr als man letztlich sieht bei den Eintrittspreisen / dem Trubel  und irgendwie ist es leider wirklich eine Massenabfertigung mit ein paar Highlights. Wenn man in Wien ist trotz allem Pflicht, vor allem wegen der Kombi-Tickets oder dem Vienna Pass. Letztlich dennoch zu hohe Eintrittspreise.

text: Bellissima residenza degli imperatori d'Austria e resa celebre dalla presenza nei suoi appartamenti della principessa Elisabetta di Baviera, meglio conosciuta come Sissi. Sia il salone dell'argenteria che le stanze appartenute a Sissi e quelle dell'imperatore Francesco Giuseppe, si rivelano come luoghi pieni di storia: le ricostruzioni dei tavoli da pranzo ancora imbanditi, le stanze private della principessa con la sua personale palestra, la scrivania dell'imperatore dove riceveva la gente, sembrano essere ancora immerse a pieno nella vita di tutti i giorni. Ci svelano il vero volto di questa casata imperiale, che nonostante la lunghissima storia viveva una vita molto semplice, fatta di impegni ma anche di piaceri. Tra il salone dell'argenteria e queste stanze ci sono moltissimi cimeli della vita di Sissi e della sua famiglia, oltre ad alcuni abiti riprodotti in copia fedele. Per certi aspetti potrebbe risultare una copia del Castello di Schonbrunn, ma rimane assolutamente da visitare essendo questa la residenza principale. L'unica cosa che potrebbe essere migliorata � l'afflusso dei visitatori, specialmente nel periodo festivo, poich� in alcune stanze e in alcuni passaggi risulta davvero esserci una calca che non ti fa godere delle stanze. � possibile fare il biglietto cumulativo anche per il castello di Schonbrunn, oltre a quello per le scuderie spagnole.
title: Hofburg Wien

text: Un paseo por la historia imperial, concentrado en el periodo de Sisi y Francisco Jos�, un palacio muy cuidado y continuas referencias a la Emperatriz,  hasta una r�plica del interior del vag�n de tren en el que viajaba. �quieres saber sus men�s? �Como era una cena "en familia " o el protocolo vien�s?, pues coge una audio gu�a y a disfrutar de la experiencia.

text: The Hofburg castle is something magic that make you feel the atmosphere of the previous centuries and understand how nobility was used to live and their general habits. Every room has a story to tell and each one of them collect a piece of history in with their clothes, beds, tools. If you like at the entrance, a person, can give you a well detailed audio guide that describes in different sections all informations and curiosities about the castle life. The tour lasts a couple of hours but it is so nice as it seems shorter. I suggest to everyone to visit it.

text: Hofburg is the heart of Vienna and the symbol of the Habsburg monarchy. You haven't been to Vienna if you did not see this place. It is worth to visit in any season of the year. If you like history make sure you check the exhibition offerings in advance so you can plan your trip accordingly. I like just to sit on a bank next to the statues to enjoy the atmosphere of the place. Mostly it's very crowdy but if you'll make an effort you'll find your relaxing wooden bank for sure. Enjoy.

text: I had the Sisi combination ticket to avoid the long queue to buy the separate ticket. But at the beginning, they said they had no more audioguide available at the moment and I had to wait for a long time to get an audioguide. But when I finally arrived at the auduoguide counter I noticed there were printed texts of what's said in the audioguide - they should have told us about this when saying no more audioguides available. Besides, the Chinese translation of the audioguide text was really terrible, there were many mistakes and some sentences that doesn't make any sense.

text: Our family's visit to the Hofburg Palace was a highlight of our trip to Vienna. Stunningly beautiful! We learned much about the Hapsburg dynasty, and especially about Empress Elisabeth ("Sissy") for whom the Viennese hold a special place in their hearts. Be sure to purchase the ticket to the Imperial Apartments and the Sissy Museum. I would also recommend getting the audioguide. Allow 3-4 hours for the complete tour.

title: Hofburg Wien

text:
A beautiful museum but very long. Prepare for a good but a long and detailed tour of the Royal Family of Austria. You are given an audio tour - take headphones as you can plug them in and get a better tour experience. I only remember toilets at the start so go to the loo before you start.

The tour is very detailed and goes through the history of the Royal Plateware and Cutlery. Then the history of Princess Sissi - the lovely but tragic daughter of the Emporer. The tour then extended into the various rooms of the Palace.

This tour is LONG. Take water. There is a restaurant part way and very nice but expensive. Unfortunately we started to run out of time at the end and as they started to close they were ushering us and others out of the rooms and giftrooms. Its hard to time your visit to fit into their hours. But a lovely visit.
title: Hofburg Wien

text: Assolutamente da visitare. Si possono vedere le 40 stanze di Sissi, Francesco Giuseppe,... Tutti gli sfarzi della monarchia. Saloni da pranzo, con tavoli apparecchiato come allora. Ci sono stanza e stanze, con i vari tipi di porcellane che utilizzavano, durante tutti i vari periodi. Numerosi candelabri e alzatine . Bellissimo. Sotto ci sono anche le scuderie, a pagamento, della scuola di equitazione spagnola

Palazzo magnifico, spettacolare e ben mantenuto.
Peccato per le informazioni minime fornite sulla storia del palazzo o dei personaggi legati alla Famiglia Asburgo e alla residenza stessa, visto che in loco non era possibile noleggiare audioguide o partecipare a tour guidati, come di norma nei siti storici-archeologici di rilievo.

Peccato per il freddo percepito in diversi saloni del palazzo. Una comunicazione in caso di momentaneo disservizio sarebbe stata gradita.

Nonostante ci�, una visita a questa meravigliosa residenza storica � un must nella citt� di Innsbruck, magari anticipata da una piccola preparazione storica.

text:
Nel palazzo reale si trova la mostra sulla vita della principessa Elizabeth, meglio conosciuta come Sissi.
Dopo la visita all'argenteria reale salute al piano superiore dallo scalone che parte dallo shop.
La mostra spiega la reale vita della principessa e di come � poi stata raccontata e tramandata stravolgendola e creando il mito che tutti conoscono.
Inoltre sono esposti molti degli oggetti appartenuti ad ella e infine le stanze reali con gli arredi originali.
Come in altri luoghi acquistando il titolo di ingresso on-line risparmierete tempo e code.

EL EXTERIOR ES MAGN�FICO. LA VISTA AL INTERIOR PESADA Y AGOBIANTE
Fue el Palacio Imperial de los Habsburgo, est� compuesto por varios edificios construidos en diferentes estilos, aunque predomina por encima de todos el barroco.
El exterior del palacio es realmente magn�fico, con su espectacular c�pula, especialmente visto desde la Plaza de los H�roes (Heldenplatz), un preciosos jard�n con una impresionante estatua y una bonita fuente, y tambi�n el frontal desde Michaelerplatz resulta espectacular.
Se puede visitar el interior en un tour dirigido aunque no con gu�a, que incluye: el Museo de Sissi (objetos personales y trajes que uso la emperatriz) que solo tiene inter�s para los fans (que fueron muchos) de aquella serie de pel�culas de Sisi-Romy Schneider de los a�os 50, pero hoy carece de inter�s, la verdad, los Apartamentos Imperiales, se visitan 19 (lamentablemente no la extraordinaria biblioteca) y es una sucesi�n de lujo y alarde, destacando el espectacular Sal�n de Ceremonias, y finalmente la Colecci�n de Plata, apabullante cantidad  de art�culos de mesa y cocina, solo interesante para los amantes de este tipo de colecciones.
El precio es de 14 euros y se pueden obtener las entradas por internet, lo que te evitar� enormes colas, y  que son v�lidas para un a�o y no reintegrables, y se puede entrar a cualquier hora. Lo peor de todo es lo incomoda que resulta la visita, vas con una masa de personas, con un calor sofocante y olores rancios de los viejos muebles de las habitaciones privadas de los emperadores.

text: If you are a horse lover you will definitely enjoy this. It does help to have a little bit of History before you go so I suggest you do the schoenbrunn Palace first. If you do go to a performance remember not to clap it can startled the horses. I didn't really see A lot of wheelchair access. And the cobblestones can be tough on your feet. The day was a little expensive but worth it.
